active_learning.discussion_prompt: In a group discussion, debate the statement: 'Perimeter-based security is sufficient for IoT environments.' Use examples from NISTIR 8259 and Zero Trust principles to support your position, addressing common misconceptions like confusing Zero Trust with traditional firewalls.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

distractor_protocol.step: Identify common misconceptions about the topic
Ensure distractors are similar in length and complexity
Include partial truths that require deeper understanding

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in university-level pedagogy (Bloom's Taxonomy, active learning, scaffolding). Generate high-quality flashcards for the topic: **Internet of Things (IoT) Security Policy** (Category: Cybersecurity; Domain: Security And Risk Management; Subdomain: Security Policy Development; Entry Domain: Advanced Policy Topics; Entry Subdomain: Emerging Technology Policies). Use the exact topic hierarchy: Level 1: Cybersecurity > Level 2: Security And Risk Management > Level 3: Security Policy Development > Level 4: Advanced Policy Topics > Level 5: Emerging Technology Policies > Level 6: Internet of Things (IoT) Security Policy. Incorporate these learning objectives: [insert learning_objectives array verbatim]. Prior knowledge: Builds on CIA triad, risk management, access control. Structure content in 4 scaffolding layers: [insert scaffolding verbatim]. Include active learning hooks: Reference discussion/peer teaching/problems in explanations. Key content: Core concepts (IoT, attack surface, Zero Trust, PAM, Supply Chain of Trust). Standards: NISTIR 8259 series (8259: Core Baseline; 8259A: Foundational Capabilities; 8259B: Manufacturer Guidance), NIST SP 800-213A, ETSI EN 303 645, OWASP IoT Top 10, IoTSF best practices, ENISA guidelines. Sources: NIST.gov (e.g., https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/ir/2020/nist.ir.8259.pdf), ETSI.org, OWASP.org/projects/iot-top-10/. Flashcard rules: Balance across Bloom's/layers (e.g., 30% REMEMBER/UNDERSTAND Layer 1; 40% APPLY/ANALYZE Layers 2-3; 30% EVALUATE/CREATE Layer 4). Mix types: 50% MCQ (exactly 3 distractors/misconceptions), 30% Short Answer, 20% True/False. Follow schema: [insert flashcard_schema verbatim]. Output ONLY a JSON array of 25 flashcards, no extra text. Ensure comprehensive coverage, measurable, and engaging for active recall.
